title: 103_s1013
content: The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" is cited in this section, which amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It addresses the estate tax treatment of land under a qualified conservation easement. The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to address the estate tax treatment of land under a qualified conservation easement. This includes excluding the value of such land from the gross estate if the executor elects to do so. If the executor elects to do so, the value of land under a qualified conservation easement can be excluded from the gross estate, as per the "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993." The term 'land subject to a qualified conservation easement' refers to land located in or within 50 miles of a metropolitan area or national park at the time of the decedent's death. The term 'land subject to a qualified conservation easement' refers to land owned by the decedent or their family for 3 years before death, located near a metropolitan area or national park, unless the Secretary determines it is not under development pressure. The text chunk discusses the ownership requirements and qualified conservation contributions for land subject to a qualified conservation easement. The text chunk explains that a qualified conservation contribution must be made by the decedent or a family member, with specific criteria for determining family members. The text chunk discusses the imposition of an additional estate tax on the first person disposing of land subject to a retained development right after a qualified conservation contribution is made. An additional estate tax is imposed on the first person disposing of property with a retained development right after a qualified conservation contribution is made. The tax amount is based on the increase in estate tax liability that would have occurred. The additional tax imposed on the first person disposing of property with a retained development right after a qualified conservation contribution is based on the increase in estate tax liability that would have occurred if the value of the development right had been included in the gross estate of the decedent. If only a portion of the property is disposed of, a pro rata portion of the tax is paid. If only a portion of the property is disposed of, the person disposing of the property pays a pro rata portion of the tax imposed. The tax is due and payable at the time of disposal. The tax imposed on property disposition is due by April 15 of the following year. A development right refers to the right to establish or use structures on the land. The term 'development right' refers to the right to establish structures for commercial purposes or conduct farming activities. The qualified conservation contribution allows for activities like farming, forestry, ranching, horticulture, viticulture, or recreation on the land. The election for this subsection must be made on the tax return under section 2001. The election for the qualified conservation easement must be made on the tax return under section 2001 and is irrevocable once made. The executor making the election must calculate the additional estate tax due. The executor making the election for a qualified conservation easement must compute the additional estate tax due and file a 'Notice of Potential Estate Tax Due' in the public record for the location of the land. The executor must compute and file the required information for a qualified conservation easement in the manner prescribed by the Secretary. Additionally, there is an amendment to the basis of property acquired from a decedent in the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new paragraph regarding the basis of property excluded from a decedent's gross estate. These amendments apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 1992, including land with qualified conservation easements granted after that date. SEC. 3. Gift tax on land with a qualified conservation easement. Gift Tax With Respect to Land Subject to a Qualified Conservation Easement: The transfer of land with a qualified conservation easement may not be considered a taxable gift under the Internal Revenue Code. The transfer of land with a qualified conservation easement is not treated as a gift for gift tax purposes. If the donor retains any development rights, an additional gift tax is imposed. If the donor retains any development rights when gifting land, an additional gift tax is imposed on the first person who disposes of the property after the gift. The tax amount is equal to the increase in gift tax liability that would have occurred if the value of the development right had been treated as a gift. The tax amount under subparagraph (A) is equal to the increase in gift tax liability that would have occurred if the value of the development right had been treated as a gift. The definition of 'development right' is provided by section 2031(c)(3)(C). The amendments made by this section apply to gifts of land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after December 31, 1992. SEC. 4. Qualified conservation contribution for land with separated surface and mineral rights. Section 170(h)(5)(B)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a special rule for contributions of property with separated surface and mineral rights. The amendment applies to cases where the likelihood of surface mining on the property is extremely low. The amendment made by this section states that contributions of property with separated surface and mineral rights will be considered met if the probability of surface mining is negligible. This amendment applies to contributions made after December 31, 1992, in taxable years ending after that date. Contributions of property with separated surface and mineral rights will be considered met if the probability of surface mining is negligible. This applies to contributions made after December 31, 1992, in taxable years ending after that date. Qualified conservation contributions, defined in section 170(h), are not considered dispositions under section 2032A of the Internal Revenue Code. This exemption applies to gifts or other contributions of qualified real property subject to a qualified conservation easement as defined in section 2031(c). Qualified conservation contributions under section 170(h) are not considered dispositions under section 2032A of the Internal Revenue Code. This exemption also applies to qualified real property subject to a qualified conservation easement as defined in section 2031(c). The amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 1992, which include land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after December 31, 1992.
